headline: India orders its airlines to check fuel switches on Boeing jets
summary: NEW DELHI (Reuters) -India on Monday ordered its airlines to examine fuel switches on several Boeing models, while South Korea said it would order a similar measure, as scrutiny intensified of fuel switch locks at the centre of an investigation into a deadly Air India crash.  The moves by India and South Korea came despite the planemaker and the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration telling airlines and regulators in recent days that the fuel switch locks on Boeing jets are safe.

The moves by India and South Korea came despite the planemaker and the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration telling airlines and regulators in recent days that the fuel switch locks on Boeing jets are safe.

headline: Silver jumps, Boeing higher, Lionsgate possible takeover: Trending Tickers
summary: Silver (SI=F) is up more than 33% this year, hitting a 14-year high as investors seek an affordable safe haven amid tightening supply and rising industrial demand. Boeing (BA) shares gain after the FAA confirmed the 787-8’s fuel switch locks are safe following a recent fatal crash linked to engine fuel flow issues. Lionsgate (LION) stock jumps again after reports that Legendary is considering a takeover during the studio’s transition post-Starz separation. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief: Market Sunrise here.

headline: Air India crash probe far from over, says CEO after preliminary report
summary: NEW DELHI (Reuters) -The probe into last month's crash of an Air India plane in Ahmedabad is far from over and it is unwise to jump to any premature conclusions, airline CEO Campbell Wilson said in an internal memo on Monday after the release of a preliminary report by investigators.  The memo, reviewed by Reuters, comes after the report depicted confusion in the cockpit shortly before the crash of the Boeing Dreamliner that killed 260 people.  Wilson added: "The preliminary report identified no cause nor made any recommendations, so I urge everyone to avoid drawing premature conclusions as the investigation is far from over."

raw.headline: Air India crash probe far from over, says CEO after preliminary report
raw.summary: NEW DELHI (Reuters) -The probe into last month's crash of an Air India plane in Ahmedabad is far from over and it is unwise to jump to any premature conclusions, airline CEO Campbell Wilson said in an internal memo on Monday after the release of a preliminary report by investigators.  The memo, reviewed by Reuters, comes after the report depicted confusion in the cockpit shortly before the crash of the Boeing Dreamliner that killed 260 people.  Wilson added: "The preliminary report identified no cause nor made any recommendations, so I urge everyone to avoid drawing premature conclusions as the investigation is far from over."
